The First Week of Siege - June 17-24, 1431

Days One and Two: Initial Bombardment (June 17-18)

The bombardment began with methodical efficiency. Master Calabrese's crews worked in practiced rhythm—load, aim, fire, swab, repeat. Every ten to fifteen minutes, another massive stone ball arced across three hundred yards and smashed into Málaga's western wall. The sound became constant: the thunder-crack of discharge, the whistling flight, the crash of impact, the rumble of falling masonry.

By the end of the first day, impact craters pocked the wall at five points where Calabrese had chosen to concentrate fire. Dust hung in the air. Defenders watched from the battlements, occasionally trying to return fire with smaller artillery from the Gibralfaro—their shots fell short or wide, more defiance than effective counter-battery.

The second day brought visible progress. Two of the impact points had become genuine excavations—holes three to four feet deep where the facing stones had been pulverized and the rubble core exposed. At night, Castilian scouts reported seeing work crews on the walls attempting repairs by torchlight.

Day Three: The Storm Arrives (June 19)

The morning of the third day dawned with oppressive humidity. By midday, dark clouds gathered over the Mediterranean. Sailors in the fleet recognized the signs—a summer squall building, the kind that struck suddenly and violently along this coast.

Admiral Enríquez sent warning: his galleys were pulling back to safer anchorage. The wind began rising around mid-afternoon, hot and gusty.

Master Calabrese ordered the guns covered and secured. "Storm coming, Your Majesty. We halt bombardment until it passes. Don't want powder getting wet."

By evening, the storm hit with full force. Rain arrived in sheets, driven nearly horizontal by howling wind. Lightning split the sky, thunder drowning out all other sound. The gun positions, built on slight slopes for drainage, became rivers. Water pooled around the massive timber platforms, then began undermining the packed earth foundations.

The siege camp turned to chaos. Tents collapsed under wind and weight of water. Men scrambled to secure equipment, move supplies to higher ground, rescue drowning gear from flash floods. The carefully organized siege works became a waterlogged mess within hours.

The Sortie (June 20, 2:00 AM)

In the darkest hours before dawn, with rain still hammering down and visibility nearly zero, the defenders struck.

They came from a sally port on the northern wall—250 picked troops moving fast through the storm. The sentries, huddled miserably in whatever shelter they could find, soaked and miserable and half-blind in the darkness, never saw them coming.

The Moors hit the forward gun positions like a hammer. Men died in their bedrolls, knives finding them before they could cry out. Others woke to screams and steel in the darkness, fighting blind in the mud and rain. Fire arrows arced toward the covered powder stores—most extinguished instantly by rain, but enough found their mark. Flames erupted from supply tents despite the downpour.

At the northernmost gun position, the attackers smashed equipment with axes, poured water deliberately into powder barrels, toppled the wooden scaffolding used for loading. One bombard's carriage—weakened by the flood—collapsed entirely when they attacked its supports.

The alarm finally spread. Crusaders from the main camp came running through the storm, splashing through ankle-deep water. Captain Fernán led a counterattack that drove the sortie back, but the Moors had accomplished their mission. They melted back toward the city, carrying their wounded, leaving thirty-four Castilian dead in the mud.

By dawn, the rain finally slackened. The damage became visible in gray morning light: one gun platform collapsed, another damaged, supplies burned or ruined, equipment destroyed or scattered, and bodies being pulled from the flooded trenches—some killed by enemy steel, others simply drowned in the flash floods.

Recovery (June 20-22)

The next two and a half days were brutal work. The bombardment remained silent while crews struggled to restore positions.

Calabrese directed operations with grim determination. "The collapsed platform must be completely rebuilt—foundation was undermined by water, can't just patch it. Need proper drainage this time." Teams hauled timbers through mud, dug drainage channels, packed stones for stable foundations, rebuilt the heavy timber framework capable of supporting a two-ton bronze cannon.

Other crews salvaged what they could. Powder barrels were opened and inspected—some contaminated by water and had to be destroyed. Damaged equipment was catalogued. The broken gun carriage required a carpenter and his team working full days to repair.

Bodies were buried with appropriate ceremony. Don Rodrigo's scouts reported that the defenders had suffered casualties too—forty-seven dead counted on the field where the crusader counterattack had caught them. Cold comfort.

The Master of Calatrava ordered the forward positions strengthened. "They won't catch us like that again. Double the sentries, even in storms. Build proper shelters for the watch. Maintain patrol routes regardless of weather."

By the morning of June 22nd, positions were restored. All five guns operational again, platforms solid, supplies replenished from the fleet.

Resumption and Progress (June 22-24)

The bombardment resumed on June 22nd with renewed intensity. Calabrese seemed personally offended by the setback. "We lost three days. Make it up. Faster loading, tighter patterns."

The walls of Málaga, which had begun showing promising damage before the storm, now bore the marks of hasty repairs—rubble packed into the impact craters, timber bracing visible, the stone facing patched with mud and smaller stones. The defenders had worked as hard during the storm as the Castilians to restore their defenses.

But repaired sections proved weaker than original construction. When bombardment resumed, the patched areas crumbled faster. By June 24th—one week into the siege—two breach points were developing again, one approaching fifteen feet wide and six feet deep, the other slightly smaller.

The naval blockade remained absolute throughout. Not a single vessel had escaped the harbor since it closed. From the Gibralfaro, observers continued watching Castilian operations, but there had been no further sorties after the storm attack.

Inside the city, smoke from cooking fires rose thinner than before. The fleet reported increased activity on the walls at dawn and dusk—work crews still repairing damage, but moving with less urgency than in the first days.

Assessment - Evening of June 24th

In the command tent, the senior officers gathered for the weekly assessment. Don Álvaro laid out the situation plainly.

"One week in, Your Majesty. We've made progress despite the setback. Two breach points forming—neither assault-ready yet, but developing. Calabrese estimates another five to seven days of sustained bombardment before they're wide enough and the rubble slopes are climbable."

He paused. "The storm cost us three days and thirty-four good men. Could have been worse—could have been better. The garrison showed they're competent and aggressive. They'll exploit any weakness."

Admiral Enríquez added his report: "Blockade holding perfectly. Nothing gets through. Their fishing fleet is idle. Food prices inside must be rising."

Don Rodrigo contributed intelligence: "Our prisoners from the sortie talk. Morale inside still solid, but the bombardment frightens civilians. The garrison commander—his name is Qaid Ibrahim al-Najjar—is respected. Professional soldier, fought against Aragon before. He's keeping them organized."

The Master of Calatrava looked at the campaign calendar. "Mid-June now. If we breach by early July and assault successfully, we could still have most of the summer campaign season remaining for other objectives. But this is taking longer than Loja did."

The tent fell quiet, awaiting Juan's response to the week's events and the path forward.
